subject: Re: [junit] Testing Method that Throws Multiple Exceptions
msgSnippet: Here is what I think is a better way: @Test (expected = Exception_A.class) public void shouldThrowA() throws Exception_A, Exception_B { // set up method_1 so
messageBody:
Here is what I think is a better way:

@Test (expected = Exception_A.class)
public void shouldThrowA() throws Exception_A, Exception_B {
// set up method_1 so it will throw Exception_A, then
method_1();
}

@Test (expected = Exception_B.class)
public void shouldThrowB() throws Exception_A, Exception_B {
// set up method_1 so it will throw Exception_B, then
method_1();
}

--
Cedric
http://testng.org



On 9/11/06, mumebuhi <mumebuhi@...> wrote:
>
> I am a newbie using JUnit 4.
>
> I try to test a method, method_1(), that is defined to throw two
> exceptions (well, one at a time), e.g. Exception_A and Exception_B.
> Thus, my test method looks like:
>
> ---start---
> @Test (expected = Exception_A.class)
> public void testMethod() throws Exception_A, Exception_B {
> try {
> method_1();
> }
> catch (Exception_A e) { throw e; }
> catch (Exception_B e) { throw e; }
> }
> ---end---
>
> Is this currently the way to achieve this? Is there a better way?
>
> Do we need to have the same number of catch blocks for each test
> method? If I want expect the test method to throw an Exception_B
> exception, then I would copy the method above and change the
> 'expected' to Exception_B.class?
